results.title: Living in sin
results.creator_credit: Tom Conway and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Man Alive”.
Three unmarried couples talk about non-marriage and the difficulties it presents for those who try it. Following an advertisement in “The Times”, couples were chosen to represent different groups: with a partner unable to get a divorce; young people looking for a trial marriage; and “commonlaw” partnerships. Reported by Jeremy James.

results.title: Living in Scotland = The Smiths in Scotland
results.creator_credit: International Film Associates (Scotland), Films of Scotland and Laurence Henson
results.brief_description: A presentation of the virtues of Scotland and its people. Roots and tradition are still important but change and development is offering new skills and resources to the world. Covers Scotland’s countryside, cities, universities, industries and its sporting opportunities, especially water sports as no part of Scotland is more than 50 miles from the water. Narrated by Bryden Murdoch.

results.title: Living in oblivion
results.creator_credit: JDI productions, Lemon sky productions, Michael Griffiths, Marcus Viscidi and Tom Di Cillo
results.brief_description: Tom Di Cillo’s acute comedy on the horrors of low-budget film making originally started life as a short film before it was extended to feature length. The unfolding dream within a dream narrative follows the perils and follies of an overworked film crew trying to get the perfect scene down on the set of a low-budget movie. Technical hiccups and budget restrictions aside, the motley group of crew members have to contend with an egotistical film star (James LeGros), a neurotic actress (Catherine Keener), their stressed out director (Steve Buscemi), his sensitive cinematographer (Dermot Mulroney), and a pissed off midget (Peter Dinklage). Clashing ego’s aside, ‘Living in oblivion’ is ultimately an affectionate tribute to the agony and ecstasy of making films and the resilient spirit of the independent film maker. Cast includes Danielle von Zerneck, Rica Martens, Kevin Corrigan, Hilary Gilford, Mathew Grace, Michael Griffiths. (Awards: 1995 Sundance Film festival, Waldo Salt screenwriting award for Tom Di Cillo, Joseph Tropiano).

results.title: Living in memory
results.brief_description: Ray Barrett delivers a potted history of Australia at war, via the exhibits in the Australian War Museum. The film begins in the 1890s and continues through to the Vietnam war mentioning aspects of the Boer War, World War I including Gallipoli, World War II, and the wars in Korea, North Borneo and Malaysia.

results.title: Living in a metropolis: Greater New York
results.creator_credit: Louis De Rochemont and Louis de Rochemont Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
This film describes New York City; population 9,000,000 (1949). Aerial views of the city and harbour, its office buildings etc show briefly its general appearance. A gateway to the United States from the East, it is a terminus for shipping, a railroad centre and has three airports. Film also includes glimpses of Park Avenue, Harlem, Chinatown, the housing projects, subways, bridges, tunnels, the food markets, restaurants, the banks on Wall Street, the garment industry and departmental stores, Central Park, Coney Island and Times Square.

results.title: Living free
results.creator_credit: Paul Radin, Columbia, Carl Foreman and Jack Couffer
results.brief_description: The sequel to “Born free” continues the adventures of Joy and George Adamson. Elsa the lioness brings her three cubs out of the wilderness to the couple who raised her. When Elsa suddenly dies, the cubs who cannot fend for themselves, attack domestic animals to survive before disappearing into the wild. The Adamson’s launch a desperate attempt to find the young lions and bring them to the safety of the game reserve. Starring Susan Hampshire and Nigel Davenport.

results.title: Living dangerously
results.creator_credit: Alan Segal and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World in action”.
Reports on the explosion of a chemical factory in Seveso, Italy and the effects of the extremely toxic dust, dioxin, that was released into the atmosphere. The substance dioxin is contained in commercial weedkillers freely available in the United Kingdom.

results.title: Living dangerously
results.creator_credit: Eric Thompson, Australian National Film Board and Richard Mason
results.brief_description: Recommends precautions against bush fires in outer-suburban and rural areas. Common fire hazards on suburban properties include undergrowth and scrub on fences, overhanging trees, cluttered spoutings, absence of fly wire on doors and windows to prevent entry of sparks; absence of incinerators and compost heaps to dispose of rubbish. In rural areas the responsibility of the inidividual is greater. The film shows examples of bad fire hazards; crops growing close to buildings; absence of fire breaks; litter strewn over properties. Stresses the need to check spark arrestors on machinery and to maintain fire fighting gear in working condition. In one year, bush fires cost the country fourteen million pounds, a loss which could have been avoided by people being wise before the event. Photography by Frank Bagnall.

results.title: Living colors = Vivre en couleurs
results.creator_credit: Francine Desbiens, ONF | NFB and Michel Hebert
results.brief_description: Charcoal drawings depict the bleak world of the worker. Pastel drawings illustrate his dreams. Oftentimes, they are dreams created by the media. Are they tailored to his real needs? Or his pocket book? This film comments indirectly on the impact of publicity and its power to develop appetites that cannot be satisfied. An animation film without words.
